Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Selection, niche breadth and plant mating system evolution: Are wider niche breadths of selfing species shaped by water limitation?
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate whether the type of plant mating system contributes to whether a plant can survive in stressful habitats. Plant mating systems, which range from self-pollinating to outcross-pollinating, where pollen has to be moved among different plants for fertilization to happen, can have significant effects on where wild plant species live. Self-pollinating species are expected to be better than outcrossing species at colonizing new areas because they do not require the presence of either pollinators or mates. This study will test the hypothesis that self-pollinating species also have physiological advantages that allow them to outperform outcrossing species in stressful, water-limited environments. The researchers will collect and analyze a variety of physiological data, such as growth rate and relative fitness, from multiple, closely-related pairs of selfing and outcrossing Collinsia plants. Results of this work will reveal important factors influencing the evolution of plant mating systems. In addition, the project will involve mentoring of undergraduate students, including individuals from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences. Planned outreach activities include the development of educational activities for elementary school children.

Recent findings support theoretical models that suggest selfing may be a niche diversifying trait because it allows colonization of new habitats lacking pollinators or mates. The proposed research builds on previous results on mating systems and niche breadth by testing whether the physiological performance of selfing species relative to outcrossers contribute to the observed repeated patterns of niche breadth differentiation between sister species pairs in the genus Collinsia. To test the hypothesis that selfers are better adapted to water-limited environments, the investigators will measure drought stress by comparing the ratio of stable isotopes 13C:12C in herbarium leaf samples of selfing/outcrossing sister species pairs relative to the 13C:12C in the international standard. They will also grow three selfing/outcrossing sister species pairs in the greenhouse in both high water and water-limited treatments and measure physiological, growth, and reproductive trait responses. Results will have important implications for our understanding of the evolution and maintenance of niche breadth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In plants, the ability to autonomously self-pollinate without a pollen vector (hereafter selfing species) can be directly or indirectly favored during colonization and can have direct and positive fitness effects during niche expansion relative to plants that require pollen vectors (hereafter outcrossing species). Thus, mating system (selfing vs. outcrossing) can be expected to exert profound effects on niche breadth of a species, but research examining general patterns between mating system and niche breadth are lacking. Given the ubiquity of selfing within flowering plant taxa and the threats facing many species may face due to climate change and habitat fragmentation, it is timely to consider the consequences mating system may have on species? niche breadth. The goal of this project is to test for emergent patterns predicted by niche and mating system theory. This research poses the broad question: To what extent does mating system influence the distribution of plant species? Does water stress directly or indirectly explain niche breadth? Do selfers and outcrossers differ in plant traits that would influence water use efficiency (flower size, flower number, leaf size, plant height)?

 

Plants living in water limited habitats typically implement drought tolerant or drought escape physiological strategies that can indirectly select on mating system. Species that are drought tolerant are more water use efficient (WUE) in low water conditions. Tolerance mechanisms include leaf stomata closure and reduced photosynthetic rates. Additionally, small flower size of selfing species may reduce water loss under drought stress relative to large-corollas of outcrossers making selfing species more drought tolerant. Thus, traits that reduce water loss can directly or indirectly favor a selfing mating system. In contrast, drought escape strategies involve rapid development and avoidance of future drought conditions. For species inhabiting time-limited habitats, selection for whole-plant rapid development indirectly leads to smaller, more rapidly developing flowers that incidentally self at greater rates for developmental reasons, or directly, when selfing is subsequently favored by selection because it hastens the time until fruit production and increases seed production in ephemeral habitats. Accordingly, selection on mating system driven by drought conditions suggests that selfing species should display strong physiological signatures indicative of drought tolerance or drought escape mechanisms. In contrast, outcrossers will exhibit less extreme values of drought-related traits.

This DDIG research aimed to quantify signatures of drought tolerance or escape using three selfing vs. outcrossing Collinsia sister species pairs that provide evidence for direct and indirect selection on mating system.

There was no geographic patterns in WUE, nor did we find consistent variation in δ13C for leaf samples for either outcrossers or selfers. Since the tested species? samples come from specimens originating from distinct abiotic conditions, these differences were expected to affect δ13C values and hence estimates of WUE. However, there are no discernible patterns in δ13C covariation with climatic variables even when analyses were conducted by species. The results show that water use efficiency, measured by δ13C, differed significantly among pairs, and there was a strong species pair  x mating system interaction. In addition, δ13C , and thus WUE, was greater for the selfing species in two species pairs, but less in the third pair, C. concolor-C. parryi. This may explain the general lack of significance of mating system in this analysis.

Plant morphological traits differed significantly between mating systems and species pairs. Significant differences in height, number of flowers, flower size and leaf size between outcrossing and selfing species were found. Overall, outcrossing species were taller, produced more flowers, larger flowers, and larger leaves. The magnitude of these trait differences depends on species pair.
